messageBody:
http://24.156.202.2:762/bin/view/Articles/TheRoleOfProgrammerTests

So said javainsel on 4/16/2003 --------------------
We want to test the creation, update and deletion of an object which
is persisted in database.

What we now do is to have three test methods for this.

In the testCreate method the object is created, checked that he is
really created and then it is deleted (we have delete because
unfortunately we don't use Mock Objects).

In the testUpdate method we create the object, update it, test the
update result and delete the created object.

In the testDelete method we create the object so that we can test
the deletion of it.

As you see, everything is included in the testUpdate method. We
duplicate much code in the other two test methods.

We write such tests for every domain object so I wonder if we should
improve our test class.

Would you write 3 or just 1 test method for that example?

And would you try to convince senior coworkers who know little about
JUnit and dislike TDD?
